conclusion: The problem involves finding the speed of an elevator at t=60 seconds using a graph of acceleration versus time.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. The area under the acceleration-time graph gives the velocity.
From t=0 to t=1 second, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t=1 to t=4 seconds, acceleration remains constant at 2 m/s².
From t=4 to t=5 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t=5 seconds to t=55 seconds, acceleration is 0.
From t=55 to t=56 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t=56 to t=59 seconds, acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s².
From t=59 to t=60 seconds, acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
The elevator starts from rest, so its initial velocity is 0 m/s.

premise: The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=0 to t=1 second is a triangle with base 1 second and height 2 m/s².
The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=1 to t=4 seconds is a rectangle with width 3 seconds and height 2 m/s².
The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=4 to t=5 seconds is a triangle with base 1 second and height 2 m/s².
The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=5 to t=55 seconds is 0 because acceleration is 0.
The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=55 to t=56 seconds is a triangle with base 1 second and height -2 m/s².
The area under the acceleration-time graph from t=56 to t=59 seconds is a rectangle with width 3 seconds and height -2 m/s².
